It is for that reason, if the Speaker is formally
absent from Westminster, I would take his

1870.57.text:
place as Chairman of Ways and Means and would
exercise in his place many of the powers that

1875.99.text:
are usually his alone - such as deciding whether
or not to grant Urgent Questions or the selection

1884.63.text:
It is unlikely but in the event of both the
Speaker and I being absent - in that case

1889.93.text:
the responsibilities would fall on the next
in line which is the first Deputy Chairman,

1895.67.text:
Eleanor Laing and after that the second Deputy
Chair.

1903.58.text:
So there are plenty of duties that come with
being Deputy Speaker. But there are also other

1908.25.text:
duties that come not with being Deputy Speaker
but that come with the historic post of Chairman

1916.59.text:
In fact the majority of my duties outside
the chamber are linked to my post of Chairman

1924.13.text:
of Ways and Means. I don't have time to run
through all the duties but I hope to give

1930.07.text: you a flavour of some of them.

1934.27.text:
The most significant additional duty both
historically and currently is the oversight

1940.23.text: of private business and private legislation.

1943.42.text:
Very broadly, private legislation is legislation
that gives particular powers and benefits

1948.91.text:
to a person or group of people - perhaps an
individual or a local authority - in addition

1955.40.text: to, or in conflict with, general law.

1959.40.text:
It is different to public legislation, the
bulk of legislation in Parliament, which applies

1965.16.text: to the population as a whole.

1967.12.text:
Until the 19th Century private bills mainly
concerned the affairs of individuals: for

1972.60.text:
example they were at that time an avenue for
securing a divorce.

1978.58.text:
From 1750 onwards however, private bills were
much more concerned with the construction

1984.02.text:
of toll roads, canals, railways and the like.
These days much of the activity is covered

1991.19.text:
by the Transport and Works Act and private
legislation is no longer required.

1996.68.text:
Most modern private bills now concern the
granting of additional powers to local authorities

2004.17.text:
The Chairman's private legislation responsibilities
pre-date his appointment as a deputy Speaker.

2009.92.text:
It was in fact the burden of duties that related
to private business - rather than the need

2015.31.text:
for help with chairing in the chamber - that
led to the appointment of the first deputy

2020.68.text: Chairman of Ways and Means in 1902.

2024.62.text:
If you imagine the amount of infrastructure
that was being built around the end of the

2029.13.text:
19th Century - all the railways, all the waterworks,
the continuation of some canals - you can

2034.44.text:
see why the private business burden was too
great for one person.

2040.95.text:
The Chairman of Ways and Means has general
oversight of private legislation with responsibility

2046.73.text:
for examining all private bills in order to
draw the attention of the House to any problems

2053.18.text:
The broader responsibility manifests itself
in a wide and complex range of specific duties

2059.09.text:
far too long to go into today but which includes
the chairing of various committees, ruling

2065.57.text: on certain aspects of procedure and process.

2068.28.text:
Perhaps the most visible part of the role
to the casual observer is the private business

2073.12.text:
on the floor of the House which is always
moved formally by myself or one of my deputies

2079.65.text: rather than a whip or minister.

2081.97.text:
The number of private and hybrid bills has
reduced significantly in the second half of

2086.28.text:
the 20th Century and private bill duties no
longer take up such as a proportion of the

2091.95.text:
office time. So myself and the clerk are not
totally reliant on all the Acts that used

2099.88.text:
But it is still a part of the parliamentary
work and a responsibility that I take very

2107.51.text:
seriously. And every now and then some extremely
significant issue pops up under private legislation

2113.23.text:
- none more so than the HS2 Bill which is
currently making its way through Parliament

2119.64.text:
as a hybrid bill subject to private business
standing orders.

2125.29.text: These are far from being trivial matters.

2130.49.text:
Another part of my responsibilities is the
oversight of committees of the whole House.

2134.50.text:
I spoke earlier about the committees of the
whole House for the ways and means and supply.

2139.70.text:
Although those particular committees no longer
meet the House does still meet as a committee

2144.26.text: on occasion as part of the legislative process.

2147.84.text:
Most bills have their committee stage in the
public bill committee, up on the committee

2153.45.text:
corridor. Some bills have the committee stage
on the floor of the House. This usually occurs

2161.27.text:
First, very short bills or emergency bills
being taken through the House in a single

2167.79.text:
day. The advantage of a committee of the whole
House is that there is no delay to the bill's

2174.03.text:
proceedings; the bill can move smoothly from
the Second reading to committee and back to

2180.09.text:
The other case is for significant or controversial
bills - often a bill making a constitutional

2186.15.text:
change. The advantage in this case is that
unlike a public bill committee where only

2191.51.text:
the members of the nominated committee can
participate, in a committee of the whole House

2196.77.text:
every MP can speak and vote as we mentioned
earlier. This is especially important for

2206.47.text:
In the case of the Finance Bill it arises
from the budget resolutions that the bill

2211.32.text:
be split into two: the more significant and
controversial of its policies are considered

2216.69.text:
on the floor of the House and the more routine
matters are considered upstairs in the bill

2225.46.text:
My own oversight of committees of the whole
House manifests itself in two main duties:

2231.74.text:
First it is the Chairman of Ways and Means
and not the Speaker who selects the group

2236.27.text:
of amendments for consideration in committee
of the whole House; second, the Speaker may

2241.54.text:
not take the chair in the committee of the
whole House so it falls to me and the deputies.

2247.68.text:
I can also choose to appoint members of the
Panel.

2250.39.text:
Appointing members of the Panel of Chairs
to chair the committee of the whole House

2255.37.text:
is something I try to do as much as possible
as it is a great experience and I believe

2262.55.text:
a great reward for the duties that they've
been carrying out.

2267.00.text:
Which brings me to the Panel of Chairs themselves,
another of my responsibilities.

2272.46.text:
There are simply too many sittings of the
House and its committees for the Speaker and

2278.24.text:
It is for this reason we have a body called
the Panel of Chairs: a few dozen Members of

2282.97.text:
the House who chair many of the House's other
proceedings.

2286.27.text:
I mentioned that the Panel members occasionally
have the opportunity to chair in the chamber.

2291.02.text: That is true but only comes very rarely.

2296.15.text:
Much more of their time is spent chairing
the proceedings of the House in the second

2300.29.text:
chamber, which is Westminster Hall, and in
General Committees: the many committees that

2306.21.text:
meet each week to consider bills, delegated
legislation and European documents. The Panel

2313.26.text:
is appointed by Mr Speaker from those members
who volunteer their services. We appoint a

2320.42.text:
balance of members so that the composition
of members of the Panel broadly reflects that

2326.51.text:
Membership of the Panel is an excellent opportunity
especially for those Members of the House

2330.92.text:
who've decided not to pursue a front bench
career.

2334.79.text:
It also allows members to engage with ranges
of the House proceedings in developing those

2340.31.text:
all important chairing skills that I outlined
earlier. Although it is not the route that

2346.43.text:
I took, it is a useful training ground for
those who may nurture dreams of being a Speaker,

2352.84.text: or a deputy Speaker themselves someday.

2355.15.text:
As Chairman of Ways and Means I have oversight
of the panel's activities. It is my office

2360.01.text:
that arranges who will chair what session
and prepares all the rotas; that shares the

2365.97.text:
information with them about procedures, keeping
them informed of all developments they need

2371.33.text: to be effective in the chair.

2374.54.text:
At the same time they feed back to me, letting
me know of any problems in committee or of

2378.36.text:
any procedural uncertainties or difficulties
where my advice or intervention might be required.

2385.31.text:
It is an extremely useful network both for
keeping the Speaker and deputies plugged in

2389.71.text:
to what is happening in committees and for
making sure the authority of the chair is

2394.45.text:
consistent and respected throughout the House
- from the height of the Speaker's chair down

2400.16.text: to the most simple delegated legislation committee.

2404.13.text:
Finally I would like to mention what I find
one of my most enjoyable duties: as Chairman

2412.18.text:
of Ways and Means I am responsible for drawing
the names in the ballot for Private Members

2417.94.text:
I'm probably most popular when the names go
into the hat and probably the most unpopular

2421.72.text: by the time they come out.

2423.78.text:
Early in each session of Parliament all backbench
Members can enter a ballot to be among the

2429.10.text:
privileged handful of Private Membersí Bills
that will get priority in the time on the

2436.82.text:
These plum-time spots are where a bill will
stand the most chance of getting through the

2440.80.text:
House and on to the statute book. And there
are hundreds of Members who enter the ballot

2446.91.text:
all in the hope of being drawn in that top
spot.

2451.12.text:
My role is to draw the top twenty names from
the hat. Last year we shook things up a little

2456.22.text:
bit and we drew the names in reverse order.
This made the whole process much more tense

2462.03.text:
and exciting both for those watching and for
those hoping that their names would be drawn

2468.32.text:
We'll now have a short video of last year's
proceedings just to show you what it looks

2521.25.text:
You can see the Clerk is a very serious chap.
We'll be holding the next ballot in the week

2571.01.text:
after the State Opening so then we will find
out who'll be following in the footsteps of

2575.53.text:
James Wharton and his European Union (Referendum)
Bill, last year's ballot winner.

2583.10.text:
The ballot is open to the public so I urge
any of you who are interested in coming into

2587.30.text:
watch - it's one of the most quirky parliamentary
occasions that still takes place.

2595.25.text:
So you'll see, there are a great many duties
that still rest with the Chairman of Ways

2599.91.text:
and Means and that is why the title of Chairman
of Ways and Means still endures even though

2605.95.text: the Ways and Means Committee no longer exists.

2608.47.text:
I and my two deputy Chairs are much more than
simply deputy Speakers even if our time in

2614.42.text:
the chamber is by far the most visible of
our work.

2618.39.text:
That is why I'm so pleased that you've come
along today to learn more about a somewhat

2622.48.text:
obscure but vitally important post which I
have the privilege to hold. I hope I've been

2630.13.text:
able to cast some light on both how the role
came into being and what it means to be the

2635.66.text:
Chairman of Ways and Means in a modern day
and age.

2640.00.text:
I also hope that you will all tune in to the
Budget statement on Wednesday to see the Chairman

2646.52.text:
of Ways and Means in action and that when
you see me in the chair you will appreciate

2650.29.text:
that it is much more than the Deputy Speaker
being given his 'day in the sun'.

2656.94.text:
Although there is certainly no longer a need
to keep the elected Speaker away from tax

2664.43.text:
and finance debates - and there hasn't been
for a long time - the presence of the Chairman

2670.37.text:
of Ways and Means in the chair on Budget day
is an important reminder to as all of the

2675.70.text:
measures that once had to be taken by the
House of Commons to first assert and then

2683.05.text: to secure its rights and independence.

2686.09.text:
I'm proud that it falls to me to continue
this tradition. I'm very much looking forward

2691.11.text: to taking the chair on Wednesday afternoon.

2693.71.text:
Thank you very much for giving your time and
for your patience. Thank you very much.
